utterances: The government has made promises to pay benefits, retirement and healthcare benefits, that the current tax structure simply can't finance.
And that seems like a tall order?
Well it is a tall order.
I mean, government spends seven billion dollars every day.
Two-thirds of that goes for interest in these entitlement or benefit programs.
And as the population ages, as more baby-boomers retire, as healthcare costs go up, it's essentially eating the federal budget alive.
And, so far, Mr. Bush has succeeded in doing nothing but making the problem worse.
His major contribution has been to cut taxes, which means less revenue, and to increase the size of the unfunded Medicare program by pushing the Medicare prescription drug program.
Even the President's budget describes this as unsustainable.
The question is, how do you get the political consensus to do something about it?
Do you have any sense of what Rob Portman's strategy would be?
Well, he hasn't shown his hand yet.

But in the end, the question is whether Mr. Portman can manage Mr. Bush, to make some concessions, perhaps talking about tax increases sufficient to get Democrats, whose support is definitely needed, to talk about cutting benefits.

I don't think that's going to happen before the 2006 elections, but I think that Mr. Portman has to be thinking about, how do I get these two sides to the table so maybe can deal with something before its too late?
David Wessel is Deputy Washington Bureau Chief of The Wall Street Journal.
Thanks for joining us.
My pleasure.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
A new film from director Hayao Miyazaki opens today here in Los Angeles, as well as in New York.
It may not sound like big news to you, but consider this: Miyazaki's last film, ""Spirited Away,"" was the highest-grossing movie of all time in Japan.
In this country, it won the Oscar for best animated feature in 2003.
Miyazaki's latest is called ""Howl's Moving Castle,"" and it's already a sensation in Japan.
Los Angeles Times and MORNING EDITION film critic Kenneth Turan has this review.
Hayao Miyazaki is the great genius of contemporary animation, and his new film is the product of a fearless visual imagination.
Howl's Moving Castle"" is based on a novel of the same name by veteran British fantasy writer Diana Wynne Jones.
It's set in an alternate universe that is half strange, half familiar.
This week, MORNING EDITION is traveling to an iconic American intersection.
It's the intersection of politics and real life: the corner of First and Main.
We're visiting a series of presidential swing states.
We're meeting voters in battleground counties, beginning in each county at First and Main Street.
This week's reporting began at the corner of First and Main in a suburban Tampa trailer park, and ranges out from there, across Hillsborough County, Florida.
The county includes the cities of Tampa, and also extensive farm regions.
The farm zone includes Plant City, Florida, a place you may have glimpsed on the news in past presidential campaigns.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

Well, the speakers are playing the hits of a past decade here at the Parkesdale market, which has been along this highway for many years and has grown from a simple fruit stand into a full-blown farmers market where you can get every kind of vegetable, depending on the season.
You can also get strawberry shortcakes and strawberry shakes, which are delicious - tiny bits of strawberry at the bottom of the cup.
We sat down with Jim Meeks, whose family has been running this place for decades, along with his daughter-in-law, Xiamara Meeks.
When people are hurting a little bit, they want to stretch the dollar, they come to places like mine.
They especially come for cheap food in the winter, which around here is strawberry harvesting season.
So if you look back over the last, I don't know, five years - I mean, since the financial crisis started, what's the pattern of business?
Did it go down at all?
Has it gone up the whole time?
We've never had a bad - never had a year less than the last one.
Some customers want more than a milkshake.
Plant City spreads out along Interstate Four, which reaches northeastward across the heart of the Florida peninsula, from Hillsborough County through Orlando and beyond.
You could think of it as a giant Main Street for Central Florida.
Politicians know this populous highway corridor contains a lot of swing voters.
If they can get this corridor on their side, they've got it made.
Everybody admits that if you take the corridor, you take Florida.
Which is why John McCain dropped by this fruit stand in 2008.
On another day, Sarah Palin's bus pulled into the parking lot.
Tried to come in with her bus and everything, but there were so many people here, she couldn't get off it.
Sarah Palin couldn't get off her bus.
She could not get off the bus.
I gave her a milkshake, and the rest of the people in the bus.
That's how busy it was.
(LAUGHTER)
They ordered to go.
OK, fine.
How much notice do you get?
When Obama came here, I didn't get any.
The guys come out here, and they say we want to bring somebody here in about 30 minutes.
I said, you can bring anybody you want to.
But we love to have people.
And I didn't know who it was until he walked in.
And but I did make a milkshake to him.
And I told him, if he didn't drink it, he would be elected.
(LAUGHTER)
I told him like that, and he laughed.
And he said, well, give me one.
Obama did win, although it was John McCain who got the vote of Jim Meeks.
Did you have anything you wanted to know from either candidate in 2008?
Not really.
Now there is.
(LAUGHTER)
I don't know, I just think - because I am an independent, little-business guy.
I think we're getting pushed around a little bit, you know.
It seems like there's going to be a bunch of new taxes and things that are going to affect us.
From what I've heard, there's going to be some, you know, more regulations and more rules and more laws.
Has anything actually changed for you?
Is the regulatory situation any different than it was a few years back?
Not really.
But I have a feeling.
We talked about this while sitting at a picnic table, in an area decorated with red and green tinsel, in honor of Plant City strawberries.
So if either of the candidates came right now, if President Obama drops by again this fall - which could happen, I suppose.
Mm-hmm.
It really could.
You might ask him about taxes...
I will.
